head.title: Suitors Raise Bid for Clear Channel

hedline.hl1: Suitors Raise Bid for Clear Channel

body.head.byline: By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN and MICHAEL J. de la MERCED
Sorkin, Andrew Ross; De La Merced, Michael J

block.p: The two private equity firms seeking to buy Clear Channel Communications have sweetened their offer, fearing that their initial bid may be rejected by shareholders.

In a letter to Clear Channel's board, Bain Capital and Thomas H. Lee Partners have proposed raising their $26 billion offer, including debt, for the nation's largest radio company, people briefed on the negotiations said yesterday. The letter proposes several alternatives, including letting shareholders co-invest in a small part of the deal, in what is known as a stub. That would allow the investors a greater return, should the deal prove successful.

The two private equity firms seeking to buy Clear Channel Communications have sweetened their offer, fearing that their initial bid may be rejected by shareholders.

In a letter to Clear Channel's board, Bain Capital and Thomas H. Lee Partners have proposed raising their $26 billion offer, including debt, for the nation's largest radio company, people briefed on the negotiations said yesterday. The letter proposes several alternatives, including letting shareholders co-invest in a small part of the deal, in what is known as a stub. That would allow the investors a greater return, should the deal prove successful.
Last week, Scott Sperling, the co-president of Thomas H. Lee, said at a conference that he was ''evaluating'' the situation, but did not say that the firms would raise their offer.
It is unclear whether the restructuring will be enough for Clear Channel's board and its shareholders, who have grumbled about the price.

Several investors in the company, including Fidelity Investments and Highfields Capital Management, a hedge fund, said they planned to vote against the current deal. Proxy advisory firms like Glass, Lewis & Company, which wield influence on how shareholders vote, have recommended rejection.

Investors were hoping for a sweetened offer of at least $1.50 a share more. Exact terms of the deal could not be learned, but they are unlikely to be given anything near that. The offer of a stub, however, could appease large investors who are expecting the company to do well.
Clear Channel has already made one drastic move to help save the deal. Last month, its board said it would postpone the date of the shareholder vote on the deal by a month, to April 19.

More notably, it moved the record date, which determines the shareholders eligible to vote on the deal, to March 23, nearly three months after the original date in January. The move was seen by some analysts as a way to get more time to persuade recalcitrant shareholders.
